greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest prime not appearing earlier that ends with A045572(n).
comment: Using Dirichlet's theorem, we conclude that every term exists. So the sequence is a permutation of the odd primes other than 5. Indeed, an odd prime p other than 5 is either in its natural place in A045572 or appears earlier than that.
link: Peter J. C. Moses, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
Index entries for primes involving decimal expansion of n
formula: a(n) >= A045572(n). The equality holds iff A045572(n) is a prime that did not already appear as a(k), k<n.
maple: if r mod 5 = 0 then r:= r+2 fi;
for x from r by d do
if isprime(x) and not assigned(Used[x]) then
